The Phantom Menace isn't just a bad Star Wars movie; it's an assault on the very senses. It's a cinematic black hole that sucks the joy out of the entire saga. Where do I even begin with this festering wound on the franchise? Jar Jar Binks. Let's just start there. A character so offensively cartoonish and grating that he makes Ewoks look like nuanced, Shakespearean figures. His dialogue is an incomprehensible babble, his movements are an eyesore, and his mere existence is a cinematic crime against humanity. But the awfulness doesn't stop with Jar Jar. The plot is a convoluted mess of trade federations, taxation of trade routes (seriously?), and political machinations that would bore even the most dedicated history professor. The child actor playing Anakin Skywalker delivers his lines with the emotional range of a block of wood, and his "romance" with Padm√© Amidala feels about as natural as a conversation with a droid with a faulty vocabulary bank. And the midichlorians! Oh, the midichlorians. This attempt to scientifically explain the mystical Force ripped away all the wonder and replaced it with space germs. It's like explaining magic by saying it's just really good glitter. The action sequences? Mostly forgettable, aside from the admittedly cool but criminally underused Darth Maul. Even the podracing scene, often cited as a highlight, drags on for an eternity. The Phantom Menace isn't just disappointing; it's actively infuriating. It took a beloved universe and dragged it through the mud, leaving a sticky residue of bad CGI and baffling creative decisions. It's a film that makes you question everything you once held dear about Star Wars. Zero out of five stars. Avoid like the plague. Burn all copies. Bury the memory.

While it introduces key themes and characters well, it often prioritizes political commentary on governmental corruption over the adventurous spirit fans expect from the Star Wars universe. The film has its flaws and may leave viewers with mixed feelings, but it remains a worthwhile watch, offering a moderately insightful message beneath its imperfections.

I've been wanting to start a rewatch of all the Star Wars films for some time, but knowing this would come first put me off for a while. It felt like it would be homework. And most of the problems I remember from the cinema release are there - Jar Jar Binks, ill conceived and badly executed in every respect; a shapeless plot; a terrible screenplay leading to wooden performances; an excess of CGI. And more. But it was more enjoyable than I expected - the actors can't really be blamed for what the script forces them into; the podracing sequence is thrilling and well-staged - thought it's telling that this standout section has little bearing on what passes for the film's plot. Imagine how exciting it would have been with genuine stakes. The lack of an antagonist is a serious issue; Darth Maul could have been it, but he's just not in it enough; imagine, again, if the JJB parts had been excised and replaced with more of Maul. The final, sprawling, action sequence is good but also suffers from the formless plot issue ... but it's more fun than I remember.

The Phantom Menace remains the most disappointing movie of my life. It only had to have been average for millions of devoted Star Wars fans to have loved it, but it feels to even reach mediocraty. From the opening scrawl talking about trade embargo's you know this isn't going to be the same level of drama as the original movies. But this film fails on every level. It seems to be aimed more at children, with a ridiculous child character capable of amazing feats and comedy droids and aliens in slapstick falls and fumbles. However, this is mixed with a long playing time and plot that centres around a trade dispute which is unlikely to captivate many children. There may be some fans of this movie out there, but I guarantee that none of them were fans of the original movies. Phantom Menace has no likeable characters, poor dialogue, a terrible plot, terrible acting and no sense of story or pace. The original movies spawned fans that could quote the movies line for line and many critics hail them as some of the best cinema has to offer. Phantom Menace is a poor movie, even if it was not linked to this legacy. I have given 2 stars, simply because of the visual effects and the John Williams score, which is the only thing that elevates it above a total failure. It is not enjoyable to watch and still leaves me wondering if it would have been better to have left Star Wars at just 3 movies.

Off course I've seen this film as a little child, deep-diving into the beautiful world of George Lucas' Star Wars. The origin story of the greatest villain of all time, introducing new fan-favorite characters and starting the era of Star Wars that brought us so much later on. But it was not like I especially liked it or anything. But I still got hyped hearing the film was gonna return to theaters for its 25th anniversary. I booked my tickets, invited a dear friend of mine to see it. After going out for dinner and walking through the town it was time to visit the theater. It already started perfectly with the trailer of Deadpool & Wolverine, PG-13 and extra exclusive scenes added in. After that, for the first time ever, I watched a Star Wars film in theaters and I fell in love with it all over again. Not only because I love Darth Maul, I loved him before in 'Rebels' and 'The Clone Wars', not only because it has the authentic Star Wars-feeling George Lucas kinda killed with shooting on digital for Attack Of The Clones, it was such a good time and beautiful and heartwarming film. Every was perfect. Easily a top 3 theater experience and a top 3 Star Wars film. I'd honestly take this over the sequel trilogy, the other prequels, Rogue One, Solo and the original Star Wars any day.

"The Phantom Menace" is a visually stunning and exciting introduction to the Star Wars prequel trilogy, introducing us to a new generation of heroes and villains. The film's CGI is groundbreaking, seamlessly blending with live-action to create a truly immersive experience. The epic scale of the film is evident in the breathtaking landscapes, bustling spaceports, and thrilling lightsaber battles. The film introduces us to Anakin Skywalker, a young and powerful Jedi with a troubled past. He is a compelling character, showcasing the potential for both good and evil within him. The film skillfully explores his complex relationship with Obi-Wan Kenobi, a mentor and friend who is trying to guide him on the right path. The dynamic between Anakin and Obi-Wan is captivating, filled with moments of both tenderness and conflict. The film also introduces us to the charismatic villain, Darth Maul, whose iconic double-bladed lightsaber and brutal fighting style make him a formidable and memorable antagonist. The lightsaber duel between Obi-Wan and Maul is a standout moment, showcasing the film's impressive action sequences. The film's pacing is a bit slower than the original trilogy, but the story unfolds at a measured pace, giving us a chance to get to know the characters and their world. "The Phantom Menace" is a visually impressive and entertaining film that sets the stage for the epic saga that unfolds in the prequels. While some critics may argue that the film lacks the charm and heart of the original trilogy, it introduces us to a vibrant and exciting new chapter in the Star Wars universe, with a cast of captivating characters and a story that promises great things to come.

I personally feel like it depends on what type of person you are when it comes to enjoying this film. If you are a kid or you like movies with great visuals and action then you would really like this film. Me and my friends went to go see this film for the 25th anniversary, two of them had never even seen the film and we all really enjoyed the movie. However, even with all of the pros there are still some cons. The acting is not the greatest and most of the time the acting just feels lifeless. If you want the audience to relate and care about the characters then you have to make them seem real, not like robots repeating a script. While there was a main objective and a threat in the film the threat did not feel like a real threat. The villains were not intimidating and you cant help but laugh at the villains. In conclusion, the average person or most people would enjoy this film but Star Wars fans and critics would not enjoy. This film is more enjoyable if you are younger, a casual viewer or if you simply appreciate the director's "George Lucas" vision. It is worth checking out, this film is very divisive so you will either like it or you will not, there is not much in between.

I know many people were unhappy with this movie and I sort of agree with them to a point. I remember paying $ for movies that were showing the trailers of this movie and they excited me for this movie In anticipation of this movie like so many die-hard fans, I camped out for this movie for the week (well we were allowed to leave for work or school). I was so excited for this movie like no other. When I finally saw the movie at the midnight opening, I was pleased and not so pleased, but there were so many things that pleased me than disappointed me. The only thing that made me not like the movie was the acting. If the acting was as good as the original trilogy the movie would have been so much better. But it can't be changed. Now the things that pleased me were the story, the action, and of course the VFX. I am one of those people who loves special effects and to me, it improves the stories. To me, George Lucas' creative mind to create aliens and alien worlds is top-notch (just like James Cameron's with Avatar). This is something I felt was incredibly missing from the sequel trilogy, which felt more Star Trek than Star Wars. Throughout the prequels, Geroge created so many great alien civilizations. I especially love the Gungans and the society. I loved Jar Jar and he should have been seen more as the unlikely hero as he was portrayed but so many see him as just the bumbling idiot. The pod racing was the best part of the movie and I wished George would have had it more in the other prequels. The final battle was a little weak but the best part of it was the Duel between Kenobi, Qui-gon, and Darth Maul. But my favorite part of the movie is the story of a little boy on his journey to becoming the greatest villain of all time, with the help of the Jedi and of course with the help of Senator Palpatine's help as well. Many die-hard fans knew who he was and that he would become the Emperor but talking with non-die-hard fans when the movie came out, they did not realize or know who he was. After re-watching the OG trilogy, thought I'd give the prequels another chance. This is a frustrating one. With what was thought to be the next epic installment in the franchise, The Phantom Menace is a boring, poorly paced and generally uninteresting start to the Prequels. I actually dozed off and had to rewind it. It The story with Naboo and the trade dispute was obviously a way of introducing Anakin and acquainting him with Padm√©, but everything else about it was so uninteresting. While there are definitely some good ideas, and some decent foreshadowing of things to come, the whole is not greater than the sum of its parts. The performances are decent. Liam Neeson is reliable as Qui-Gon Jinn and Ewan McGregor turns in a more limited but still impactful performance as Obi-Wan. I also have to give props to the acting from the younger cast members. The visual elements are overdone though. I understand the film came out over twenty years ago, so the CGI won't be as good, but goodness, it's just really bad in this. Nothing feels authentic. I wish George Lucas had used more practical effects as he did in the OT. John Williams does deliver a great score, but that's as far as my praise can go. These were always seen as divisive and I think I now remember why.

Cast your mind back to May 1999. You may remember quite a buzz of excitement in the air. The world was awaiting the release of a new edition to the Star Wars saga, 16 years after it ended. To put it mildly, The Phantom Menace had a lot to live up to. It may yet go down in history as the most divisive film of all time. As often parodied, it split Star Wars fans down the middle. No one could deny that the effects were superb, flawless even. But what bothered many was the clunky dialogue, the wooden acting and the fact that it didn't seem to belong in quite the same world as the series which shares its name. My main problem with the Phantom Menace is that I'm relatively indifferent to it. It's not awful by any means, in fact it has many redeeming features (but no where near enough to make it a great film). The visuals were the best in the world at the time of the film's release, and still hold up today. The realization of Coruscant, the "capital of the galaxy" in the form of a planet-wide city is an interesting idea, as is the Gungan's underwater "bubble city" and both look sensational. The film also has two stand-out action sequences - the pod-race, a creative, heart-thumping Ben-Hur tribute, and the "duel of the fates" which forms the finale of the film. This three-way lightsaber battle between a young Obi-Wan Kenobi (Ewan McGregor) and his master Qui-Gon Jinn (Liam Neeson) against the formidable Darth Maul (Ray Park) wielding an iconic double-bladed lightsaber. This has to be among the finest fight scenes of all time - the choreography is extremely creative and the execution flawless - it's a real testament to the stunt crew working on the film. Brilliant visuals and two memorable scenes cannot save a film, however. The story isn't up to much, and you don't have the high stakes of the original films - you know who's going to survive, it being a prequel to the original series. Lucas has never been great at dialogue, but during his Star Wars prequels, he seems to become worse at it over time. In the Phantom Menace you can look forward to such gems as Obi-Wan's "do not defy the council master, not again", young Anakin's "Are you an Angel?" speech, Yoda's classic "how feel you?" and pretty much everything said by Jar-Jar Binks. Ah Jar-Jar Binks - no other three words send shivers down the spine of a Star Wars fan so effectively (accept maybe a debate into who shot first). He's a truly irredeemable character - narratively unnecessary, insulting, and very, very annoying. The other actors and their characters are either unremarkable (MacGregor, Lloyd and Portman) or look thoroughly embarrassed to be on screen (I'm talking about you, Mr Neason). The Phantom Menace is a disappointment, but in truth, it could never live up to Star Wars fans' high expectations, but it's good for providing the odd cheap thrill. And John Williams' scoring for the series is still great.

Star Wars: Episode I The Phantom Menace is a polarizing entry in the iconic franchise that had lofty expectations to live up to its predecessors. Director George Lucas returns to the galaxy far, far away with a visually ambitious film that showcases groundbreaking special effects and epic set pieces. However, the film is burdened by convoluted plotting, wooden performances, and an overemphasis on CGI that often overshadows the heart and soul of the original trilogy. While Ewan McGregor brings charisma to the role of Obi-Wan Kenobi and the introduction of Darth Maul injects a much-needed dose of menace, the film sometimes struggles to capture the magic and depth of its predecessors. Despite its flaws, "The Phantom Menace" remains a noteworthy addition to the Star Wars saga, offering moments of spectacle and nostalgia for die-hard fans, but leaving a sense of disappointment for those seeking the narrative coherence and emotional resonance that made the original trilogy so beloved.

As someone who wasn't previously a big fan of Star Wars, I decided to give the series another chance and watch all the movies from the beginning. While it may not be the best Star Wars film out there, The Phantom Menace offers plenty of exciting moments and an intriguing storyline that kept me engaged throughout. I found myself invested in the characters and their journeys, even if some of the dialogue and acting was a bit stiff at times. Overall, I would highly recommend giving The Phantom Menace a chance, even if you're not a diehard Star Wars fan. I kicked off my Star Wars rewatch with Episode 1 The Phantom Menace. This movie is a very complicated movie to judge. Part of me values this movie mode then most due to the extreme amount of nostalgia I have for the Prequels. Whereas part of me sees the horribly written dialogue and struggles to give this a good rating. I decided to go into this completely open minded and with a movie critic mindset. People don't talk about the world-building in The Phantom Menace enough. The Gungans, the Jedi Council, the Sith + The Rule of Two, the Senate, the political structure for all of the new planets, and countless other examples of world-building. George Lucas is a genius when it comes to this stuff. People are always talking down upon this movie because of the dialogue and writing but completely ignore the other outstanding examples of filmmaking from George Lucas. The lightsaber choreography is jaw dropping. The fight with Darth Maul, Obi-Wan, and Qui Gon is one of, if not the best lightsaber duels in the entire franchise. I've always said that John William's best work is the Star Wars Prequels and listening to the score of this movie further proves that. There are so many iconic tracks in this movie. Most notably, Duel of the Fates. My absolute favorite song in the entire franchise. Liam Neeson as Qui-Gon Jin is perfect. Qui-Gon is such a fantastic character and is an amazing addition to the franchise. Ewan McGregor as Obi-Wan is perfect and that's further displayed throughout the rest of the trilogy. I love Jake Loyd as a young Anakin Skywalker. It's a shame that he received a ton of hate for this role. I thought his acting was great for his age. He could've had a promising career if it weren't for all of the hate he received. Despite the terrible dialogue and CGI, The Phantom Menace sets up an era of Star Wars that is home to some of the best stories in the entire franchise.
Cringey dialogue, bad acting and horrible script writing. Enjoyable lightsaber fights, John Williams music, and Liam Neeson save this Star Wars parody.

This is actually a bad film. I can explain more clearly - there would be people that unfairly dismiss high production 80s fantasy as being "just about visuals" as if props, concept art and visual effects "were the movie". Obviously, this overlooks the dynamic cast, great music, tought plotting and classic villains in the original Star Wars film trilogy. Getting down to it, this movie - probably one of the most anticipated genre films of it's decade - has NO clearly defined lead character. It features a cast of actors defined almost entirely by what they wear, and boy are there a lot of overstated costumes and backdrops in SW ep1: tPM. The film also bores (and confuses) people as director George Lucas introduces a bickering space senate, treaties, trade embargoes, tax disputes and so on and on. He's: Not Very Good at this type of story. The main things Lucas did well previously was create proportion, space, physicality and a dynamic cast. Not only are the new characters characterless, but the attempts to make a serious plot about "profits", "losses" and "diplomacy" is riddled with lifeless dialogue. Any (grown up) film maker knows these things are staged for dramatic resonance, not just to airlessly waffle about among overstuffed scenes. That's the real point of the movie, really: the overproduced set pieces. While impactful back then, they just seem cluttered and look like dated computer animation now. The original Star Wars concept artist Ralph McQuarrie, a key player responsible for the hugely successful Star Wars design aesthetic has been replaced by new staff that like: insectile, weak robot armies, clunky looking CGI space craft and, yeah, absurd overstatement. Where three well designed buildings would sit great in a shot, now there's dozens or hundreds of them. The urge to "outdo" any other production facility by stuffing in more and more geometry, fake lighting and clutter simply engulfs the (bland) cast onscreen. Followed by two sequels, both similarly unlikeable although the second one has an absurd ending, and the third a visually impressive and slightly less absurd ending. Avoid.

Sadly, this film marked the turning point of the Star Wars franchise. While not the worst film in the series (although it is pretty bad, ngl) it still got the trilogy to a pretty good start. We get a deeper insight into the character we met in A New Hope, Obi-Wan. We see the history between him and Lukes's Father, Anakin (known as Darth Vader throughout the first trilogy). Some cringy jokes and a few less-than-stellar scenes later, we get to the part where we learn how Obi-Wan came to be Anakin's trainer. While not very good in general, it got the series off to an ok start.

I get the feeling that George Lucas wasn't 100% sure whether he was making Star Wars for a new generation of kids, or making Star Wars for the adults who grew up on the original films. Understandably, the result is that the film suffers from people alternately complaining that it's too politics-heavy to be a kids' film. Or too slapstick to be an adults' film. Whichever side you're on, if you can put aside the bits that don't appeal to you (and the bits that don't appeal to anyone), then it's a fun way to spend a couple of hours of your life.

George Lucas made big news when he picked up on the original three films that would begin the great Star Wars saga in 1999, twenty-two years after the original three films debuted. "Star Wars: Episode I- The Phantom Menace" certainly utilizes the numerous advances that special effects and moviemaking have evolved into, unfortunately it lacks the character development and depth of the original trilogy. Hopefully now that the stage has been set we will see a return to form in the next two films and how they blend into the Star Wars mythos. The film had quite the story to live up to and while it falls way short, hopefully they will grow and fall in line with the masterpieces of the original trilogy.

Star Wars: Episode 1- The Phantom Menace is definitely worth a watch, but I do think it is one of the weaker movies of the Star Wars saga. I will admit I wasn't expecting much after reading some very negative reviews on IMDb, but I do think this particular instalment did in some ways exceed my expectations and disappointed as well. On a visual and technical level, it looks absolutely fantastic, with splendid special effects, stunning cinematography and fine scenery and costumes. The script is fairly decent, perhaps lacking the sophistication of Empire Strikes Back or New Hope, but does have some memorable lines. The action is constantly exhilarating, and Darth Maul, well played by Ray Park is a very good villain. Of course though, Darth Vader is better. Most of the performances are very good, especially Natalie Portman as Queen Padma who looked stunning and Jake Lloyd as Anakin Skywalker who shone with his confident charm. And Jar Jar Binks is okay on the most part, and you have to love Yoda. And the music score by John Williams was outstanding, definitely one of his best works. The quality of sound and direction are also impressive. However, there were things about this film that did disappoint. One is despite the awesome visuals, strong music score and good characters, the story never quite distinguished itself. It did take a while to get going, and when it did try to get going and you could tell it wanted to, it was further disadvantaged by the uneven pacing. Liam Neeson is a fine actor, his performances in Kinsey and Schindler's List are proof of that, and I do like Ewan McGregor. But as Qui-Gon Jin and Obi Wan Kenobi, both stars give unusually wooden performances, and at times looked even embarrassed. And as I said, the pacing is very uneven, there are some slow moments, and one or two scenes felt rushed. All in all, maybe disappointing for fans of the saga, but it cannot be denied that visually it is an accomplishment. 7/10 Bethany Cox
